solution.text:
A very large distance cannot always be expressed in the form of kilometers.
They're expressed in the form of light years.
One light year is the distance travelled by light in one year.
Remember that the speed of light is \(3 \times 10^5 \frac{km}{s}\)
Therefore, \(1\) light year \(=3 \times 10^5 \times 1 \,year \qquad\) [Distance\(=\)Speed\(\times\)Time]
\(=3 \times 10^5 \times 365 \times 24 \times 60 \times 60 \qquad\)[Converting 1 year to seconds]
\(=9.46 \times 10^{12}\) kilometers

content.text:
Very large distances between two celestial objects is expressed is another unit known as 'light year.'
One light year is equivalent to :

correct.text: The distance travelled by light in one year
